title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SAN ANTONIO – In the rarefied air of basketball’s record books, some performances are simply untouchable. At the HemisFair Arena on this 1998 night, David Robinson authored one of them.

The San Antonio Spurs, powered by a superhuman and historic 40-point, 15-rebound explosion from “The Admiral,” routed the Boston Celtics 101-86. The final score was a mere formality; the true narrative was Robinson’s complete and utter dominance from the opening tip.

Robinson was a force of nature, operating with an unstoppable blend of power and finesse. He owned the paint, converting seemingly every opportunity near the rim and controlling the glass with 15 defensive rebounds. The Celtics had no answer for the seven-foot-one center, who carved through their defense with a performance for the ages.

While Robinson was the undisputed star, he received crucial support from Sean Elliott, who chipped in 18 points and 6 assists, and Vinny Del Negro, who added 14 points. Their contributions provided the necessary balance to Robinson’s one-man wrecking crew. For the Celtics, Antoine Walker led a futile charge with 20 points, but the team’s efforts were ultimately swallowed whole by the Robinson-led Spurs defense.

The victory was a definitive statement from the Spurs, built on the broad shoulders of their legendary center. On a night where one man transcended the game, the story wasn't about a team win, but about a historic individual masterpiece that will forever be etched in the annals of NBA lore.
